p: CMV infection is mostly asymptomatic among the general population; however, around 10% to 15% of infants with congenital CMV infections may be at risk of sequelaes such as mental retardation, jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, microcephaly, hearing impairment, and thrombocytopenia [ 39, 40, 41, 42]. Among these sequelaes, the most devastating one is the CNS sequelae related to neurodevelopment, because CNS injury is irreversible and persists for life, including mental retardation, seizures, hearing loss, ocular abnormalities, and cognitive impairment [ 43, 44, 45]. This means the asymptomatic newborns with congenital CMV infection still have an increased risk for long-term sequelae, especially, mental retardation and sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) [ 46, 47, 48, 49], making CMV the leading nonhereditary cause of SNHL [ 42, 50].
